metadata.case_name: Fauja Singh Gill v. K.S. Sidhu & Ors.

facts.text: Respondent Sidhu appointed as Subordinate Judge on 27 October 1948 in former Pepsu State.
Respondents Vohra and Jain appointed as Subordinate Judges in Punjab Provincial Civil Service (Judicial Branch) on 4 August 1950.
Appellant appointed as Subordinate Judge in Punjab Provincial Civil Service (Judicial Branch) on 7 August 1950.
Respondent Sidhu appointed as officiating/temporary Additional District and Sessions Judge on 15 January 1966 in Punjab.
Respondent Jain appointed as Senior Subordinate Judge in Delhi on 12 October 1966.
Appellant appointed as Additional Senior Subordinate Judge on 12 October 1966.
Delhi High Court established on 31 October 1966.
Punjab reorganised on 1 November 1966; Sidhu, Vohra, Jain allocated to Punjab; appellant to Haryana.
Select list prepared by Delhi High Court in November 1966 showing appellant junior to respondents 2-4 for Delhi Judicial Service.
Respondent Vohra appointed Assistant Sessions Judge, Delhi on 17 March 1967.
Respondent Vohra promoted and appointed temporary Additional District and Sessions Judge, Delhi against permanent post on 24 April 1967.
Respondent Sidhu transferred to Delhi and appointed Additional District and Sessions Judge on deputation on 1 May 1967.
Respondent Jain promoted as Additional District and Sessions Judge in Punjab Superior Judicial Service on 23 June 1967 while on deputation.
Respondent Jain promoted and appointed temporary Additional District and Sessions Judge, Delhi against temporary post on 11 August 1967.
Appellant promoted as Additional District Sessions Judge in Haryana on 28 July 1967 while on deputation as Senior Subordinate Judge, Delhi.
Appellant appointed temporary Additional District and Sessions Judge, Delhi against temporary post on 25 November 1967.
Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1970 promulgated on 27 August 1970.
Appellant confirmed as District and Sessions Judge in Haryana on 2 October 1970 while functioning as Additional District Sessions Judge on deputation.
Respondent Sidhu confirmed as District and Sessions Judge in Punjab on 22 February 1971 while functioning in Delhi on deputation.
Gazette Notification dated 15 May 1971 appointing respondents Sidhu, Vohra, Jain and appellant substantively to Delhi Higher Judicial Service in that order of seniority.
Appellant and respondents assumed charge as Additional District and Sessions Judges, Delhi in Delhi Higher Judicial Service on 17 May 1971.
Appellant made representation to Delhi High Court against seniority fixation on 1 September 1971.
Delhi High Court rejected appellant's representation on 23 October 1971.
Delhi High Court judgment and order dated 21 March 1972 in Civil Writ No. 1211 of 1971.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court from Delhi High Court judgment dated 21 August 1972.

legal_issues.text: Construction of Rule 6(3) of Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1970: whether 'length of service rendered by them in the cadres to which they belong' refers to length of service in substantive permanent posts (date of confirmation) or total length of service as District/Additional District Judges regardless of permanent/temporary capacity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Length of service under Rule 6(3) means service in substantive permanent posts as District/Additional District Judges; appellant confirmed earlier than Sidhu on 2 Oct 1970 vs 22 Feb 1971; Vohra and Jain not confirmed, belong to lower cadre.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules 1970 Rule 6(3); 1958 SCR 828 at 842-843; Art 14, 16 Constitution; GOI Home Ministry memo 22-12-1959; Punjab Superior Judicial Service Rules 1963

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Cadres' in plural indicates separate cadres of permanent District Judges and Sub Judges working temporarily as Additional District Judges; temporary officers belong to Sub Judge cadre.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules 1970 Rule 6(1), 6(3); dictionary meanings of 'cadre' and 'belong'

petitioner_arguments.text: Seniority based on confirmation date aligns with general principles and avoids treating unequals equally, ensuring constitutional validity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art 14, 16 Constitution; Punjab and Haryana Superior Judicial Service Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 6(3) refers to total length of service as District/Additional District Judges functioning in Delhi, irrespective of permanent/temporary; respondents appointed earlier than appellant: Sidhu 1 May 1967 (prior officiating 15 Jan 1966), Vohra 24 Apr 1967, Jain 11 Aug 1967 vs appellant 25 Nov 1967.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules 1970 Rule 6(1)(a), 6(3), 6(4); Fundamental Rules 9(4); Punjab Superior Judicial Service Rules 1963 Rule 12 (not adopted)

respondent_arguments.text: 'Cadres to which they belong' means state-wise cadres from which deputed; cadre includes permanent and temporary posts; avoids absurd results as most were temporary.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules 1970; Webster's Dictionary; FR 9(4); 1969 Service Law Reporter 622; AIR 1971 P&H 113

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant ranked junior pre- and post-reorganisation; opted for absorption knowing position.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules 1970 Rule 6(3)

court_reasoning.text: Delhi Rules framed for 11 officers functioning as Additional District Judges in Delhi, mostly temporary; Rule 6(3) focuses on length of service rendered as District/Additional District Judges, not limited to substantive permanent posts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fallacy to equate cadre with substantive permanent post; most recruited from temporary capacities.

court_reasoning.text: Cadre post includes temporary posts per Delhi Rules and FR 9(4); 'cadres to which they belong' covers permanent and temporary Additional District Judges.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents rendered longer service as Additional District Judges: Sidhu (earlier than 25 Nov 1967), Vohra 24 Apr 1967, Jain 11 Aug 1967 vs appellant 25 Nov 1967.

court_reasoning.text: Confirmation in home states accidental; basing seniority on confirmation wipes out actual service length; Rule deliberately did not adopt Punjab Rule 12 on confirmation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Criterion is length of service in cadre (District/Additional District Judges) at initial constitution.

holdings.text: Under Rule 6(3), seniority determined by length of service rendered as District or Additional District and Sessions Judges in permanent or temporary capacities, irrespective of confirmation dates.

precedents_cited.relevance: Appellant cited for substantive appointment giving rights and temporary not belonging to cadre; court held not relevant.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs initial recruitment and seniority based on length of service in cadres; interpreted to include temporary service.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Superior Judicial Service Rules, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines cadre post as permanent, ex-cadre as temporary; seniority by confirmation not adopted in Delhi Rules.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant argued equality requires distinguishing permanent/temporary; court upheld interpretation as valid.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Reorganisation Act, 1966
statutes_cited.relevance: Led to allocation of officers to Punjab/Haryana.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines cadre, permanent post, temporary post; cadre includes temporary additions.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Delhi High Court's decision and the notification fixing seniority of respondents K.S. Sidhu, O.N. Vohra and J.D. Jain above the appellant in the Delhi Higher Judicial Service based on longer length of service as Additional District and Sessions Judges.

key_quotes.text: "The seniority of the candidates appointed at the initial constitution shall be in accordance with the length of service rendered by them in cadre to which they belong at the time of their initial recruitment to the service"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of Rule 6(3) central to dispute.

key_quotes.text: The criterion for the determination of seniority under the Delhi Rules is the length of service rendered by the candidates during the period when they were rendering service either as District Judge or as Additional District and Sessions Judge in permanent or temporary capacities.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of Rule 6(3).

key_quotes.text: To confine cadre to permanent posts under the Delhi Rules would be to render the Rules totally unworkable and impracticable because at the time of initial recruitment the persons came on deputation from States mostly in their temporary capacity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
